definition: to lift/to raise/to raise one's head/high/high spirits/soaring/expensive

sentences.english: Yes, testing is expensive, but production outages can be more so.
sentences.chinese: 是的，测试费用相当高昂，但生产损耗可能会更大。

sentences.english: On this high note the puppet show commences .
sentences.chinese: 木偶戏就在这阵高昂的调子里开场了。

sentences.english: But the price for such solidarity will be very high.
sentences.chinese: 但毫无疑问这种团结的代价将无比高昂。

sentences.english: We hope that we can come out of the Stadio Franchi with our heads held high.
sentences.chinese: 我们期望我们可以高昂着头走出法兰齐体育场。

sentences.english: A disunited nation has to incur unduly high costs of government.
sentences.chinese: 一个分裂的国家必须担负过度高昂的政府费用。

sentences.english: The cost of today's micro-irrigation systems, however, is still high.
sentences.chinese: 然而，目前的微灌系统的成本仍然是高昂的。

sentences.english: But the high price of it makes a lot of demanders hang back.
sentences.chinese: 然而路由器的高昂价格却令许多需求者望而却步。

sentences.english: Rita bought the ring despite the high price.
sentences.chinese: 尽管价格高昂，莉塔还是买下了这枚戒指。

sentences.english: To keep up my pace, I drank two pots of coffee each day.
sentences.chinese: 为了保持快节奏的精神高昂，我每天要喝两壶咖啡。

sentences.english: Morale is better with a more casual dress-code.
sentences.chinese: 比较宽松的服装规定会有比较高昂的士气。

sentences.english: Some fans of the "beautiful game" are balking at the cost of long-haul flights and peak-price accommodations.
sentences.chinese: 一些球迷被长途飞机的票价及高昂的住宿费吓跑了。

sentences.english: Then you may need to pay high interest.
sentences.chinese: 那么也许你需要支付高昂的利息了。

sentences.english: Expensive to maintain, though, only the wealthiest states can afford them.
sentences.chinese: 宪兵骑士维护费用高昂，只有富庶国家方有财力成军。

sentences.english: Why would anyone be sexually excited by shoes?
sentences.chinese: 为什么会有人被鞋子撩得性致高昂呢？

sentences.english: The cost of the reprieve was high, however.
sentences.chinese: 然而，缓刑成本是高昂的。

sentences.english: Alcatraz closed in 1963 because of high operating costs.
sentences.chinese: 由于高昂的运营成本，监狱在1963年被关闭。

definition: to surge up/to rise/(of tensions etc) to run high
low/beneath/to lower (one's head)/to let droop/to hang down/to incline
(of prices, rates etc) to remain high
to clamber up/(of prices etc) to rise
easily/readily/frequently/at every turn/at the slightest pretext
